Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Elucidating the mechanisms by which enzymes - proteins that accelerate chemical reactions-- control chemical reactivity is among the most exciting challenges in contemporary life sciences. To comprehend cells' inner workings it is particularly important to understand how enzymes fine tune their ability to bind specifically their reaction partners and accelerate only the desired reaction. This research focuses on the unique chemistry of a family of enzymes that utilizes the rare amino acid selenocysteine. These selenoenzymes are highly efficient and exhibit a unique capacity to escape inactivation by reactive oxygen species, i.e. toxic chemicals that are formed during energy production. The project utilizes biophysical approaches to study these properties and their molecular origins in detail by focusing on commonalities among the selenoenzymes. Thus, the intellectual merit of this research arises from understanding the specialized chemistry performed by selenoenzymes and how it supplements and integrates with the commonly used sulfur-based chemistry of the abundant amino acid cysteine. It will reveal the fundamentals that govern selenoenzymes function and, more generally, enzyme operation and regulation.

Broader Impact
The broader impact of this project arises from the creation of a research and educational environment -both in the classroom and in the laboratory- that emphasizes the training of the students' systematic and logical reasoning skills. Furthermore, it seeks to nurture the students' confidence to apply these tools to independently seek and evaluate information. The ideal is to share the pleasures and responsibilities of science. This is achieved by expanding the biochemistry curriculum to incorporate active learning and inquiry-based teaching methods to emphasize learning concepts. The goal is not only to better prepare a wide audience from many disciplines for their prospective careers, but to also enhance their interest in science and its contribution to contemporary life. To diversify and expand participation in science, a unique summer program will provide college students with physical and learning disabilities with specialized career advice, networking opportunities, and examples of career paths of scientists who faced similar adversities. The goal is to prepare and to encourage these college students, who typically leave the sciences, to pursue graduate studies in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological catalysts make life possible by controlling cellular substances, the chemical processes that take place between these substances, and the transformation and use of energy. The universal search to understand the phenomenon of life is the quest to formulate the fundamental physical principles that govern these conversions and the resulting complex behavior of the cell. Such principles will explain how the chemical reactivity of these biological catalysts – namely, enzymes – is fine-tuned and regulated in order to operate successfully in an environment that is dynamic, heterogeneous, and constantly restructuring.

Studies funded by “CAREER: Reactivity of Selenoproteins” focused on the role of selenium in proteins. Selenoproteins are largely involved in signal transduction and detoxification pathways. Despite their physiological importance, the precise function of only a small fraction of the selenoproteome is known. We investigated general thematic questions pertaining to selenoproteins function and the way in which they contribute to the antioxidant defense of the cell.

Biochemical Characterization of Selenoproteins 

Procuring selenoproteins in sufficient quantities for biochemical studies has been a persistent problem in the field. This is because unlike all 20 canonical amino acids, selenocysteine is encoded by a codon, which also encodes for the termination of the protein synthesis. To break the gridlock of sample preparation, we have developed novel approaches that utilize an amide-forming reaction to generate peptides and proteins from their respective fragments.  This biochemistry-friendly, inexpensive approach allows us to successfully prepare -in the necessary quantities- native human selenoproteins whose enzymatic function has yet to be determined. Thus, this work significantly expands the ability of the scientific community to produce a large part of the selenoproteome. This novel native chemical ligation method is also useful for the production of proteins that do not contain selenium in their final form and thus enables new lines of research in other disciplines.  

Redox Potentials of Selenoproteins

The redox potential indicates a protein’s tendency to gain electrons. The higher the affinity for electrons is, the more positive is the redox potential. In the cell, the redox potential influences protein communications and interactions. While many factors can influence redox potentials, exactly in which way is still unknown, as only a few selenoproteins’ redox potentials had been measured previously. We have recorded the redox potentials of numerous native selenoproteins and their cysteine counterparts. Our study illuminated both commonalities and differences between the reactivity of selenocysteine and cysteine.

Biological 77Selenium Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy

Our work on selenoproteins also involved developing approaches based on the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) technique. NMR exploits interactions between magnetic fields and a nucleus to detect its chemical environment. (i.e. chemical bonding, non-bonding interactions, conformational mobility etc.). We have developed procedures for enrichment of proteins with 77selenium (the selenium isotope compatible with NMR), and worked towards a comprehensive knowledge base and data interpretation of selenium NMR spectroscopy of biological samples.

To pinpoint the difference between selenoproteins from proteins that rely on cysteine, we looked systematically at the influence of the selenocysteine environment in the context of redox motifs (i.e., the common patterns of amino acids that typically activate selenocysteine). In the majority of selenoproteins, the reactive selenocysteine forms a bond with a neighboring Cys positioned up to two amino acids away. The nature of the residues forming this redox motif and the size of the ring formed when the cysteine and selenocysteine are expected to control its reactivity. We probed the conformations and mechanics of these redox motifs using selenium NMR spectroscopy. Theoretical calculations of the NMR parameters were used to understand the conformational preferences of the rings. The calculations provide a comprehensive interpretation of selenium chemical shifts that should be generally helpful in further investigations of biological systems by selenium NMR spectroscopy.

Broader impact: Increasing Participation of Students with Disabilities in STEM

Students with disabilities are a significantly underrepresented demographic in STEM. To remedy such underrepresentation, my colleague Dr. Karl Booksh and I have developed a unique summer outreach program called “Research Experience for Undergraduates Science and Engineering Leadership Initiative.” This groundbreaking NSF-funded program encourages undergraduates with physical and learning disabilities to share in the joy of science. Our specific goal is to increase retention of this underrepresented group, empowering them to stay in research and professions related to STEM disciplines. The program has drawn considerable interest from other universities wishing to implement similar programs or learn from our experience how best to accommodate students with disabilities in research laboratories. A description of the program can be found at Chemical and Engineering News – (http://cen.acs.org/articles/92/i35/Research-Experience-Students-Disabilities.html). Our program, initially supported by this NSF career grant, has by now been funded independently and just welcomed its fifth cohort. Many of our previous REU students are now attending graduate and professional programs, thus demonstrating that our program can successfully assist students with disabilities to enter into and remain in STEM professions.
